Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Intermediate Band Semiconductor Materials for High Efficiency Solar Energy Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Materials World Network focuses on efficient solar energy conversion via intermediate electronic states in II-VI-O compound semiconductors in collaboration between researchers at The University of Michigan (US) and the Instituto de Energia Solar at the Universidad Polit√©cnica de Madrid (Spain). Intermediate states in the bandgap of a semiconductor material provide multiple optical transitions and corresponding optical absorption bands. Solar cell devices based on these materials offer a potential route to high efficiency using a material with three defined absorption bands in a simplified one-junction structure. The introduction of oxygen isoelectronic impurities in II-VI compound semiconductors show promise in realizing optical transitions with high radiative efficiency and energetic positions well matched to the solar spectrum. While these materials are well suited for highly efficient solar energy conversion, major advances in material synthesis and the understanding of optoelectronic properties are required. The primary technical objectives of this project are 1) the theoretical and experimental study of oxygen states in II-VI materials, 2) characterization of multi-photon optical transitions in II-VI-O materials, and 3) determination of charge carrier transport in via intermediate electron states.

Research on intermediate band materials will directly impact photovoltaic solar cell technology, where the projected high efficiency and simplistic single-junction device design would lower the cost of solar energy conversion. This project will contribute to the education of graduate students by funding research abroad, exchange of scientists, and the establishment of a seminar series. The partnership will also enhance existing educational efforts at the University of Michigan, where freshman in the Engineering 100 course on photovoltaics and solar-powered systems will have a connection to a leading solar energy institute as a part of their team project to design and implement a system powered by solar energy.

This project is jointly funded by Division of Materials Research (DMR) and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The viability of solar energy critically depends on the energy conversion efficiency of the active materials, which determine both the power production per unit area and ultimately the cost of electricity produced. New approaches for efficient solar energy production have been explored, including intermediate band solar cells. An intermediate band solar cell utilizes semiconductor materials that possess intermediate electron states within the bandgap to provide a path for the excitation of charge carriers to the conduction band using multiple photons at energy lower than the bandgap energy of the material. The intermediate electron states effectively provide multiple optical absorption bands in the material, which may result in more efficient conversion of solar energy. Despite the high thermodynamic limits for solar energy conversion using intermediate electronic states in semiconductors (~60%), demonstrations of improved efficiency over standard semiconductors have been very limited. Highly radiative states provided by oxygen incorporation in ZnTe appears to be an attractive approach for realizing efficient intermediate band solar energy conversion, with desirable energetic transitions. This project established an international collaboration between the University of Michigan (U-M) and the Instituto de Energia Solar at the Universidad Politécnica de Madrid (IES/UPM) to study intermediate band solar energy conversion in II-VI-O materials. The research combined expertise in II-VI-O materials and devices at U-M with expertise in intermediate band solar energy conversion and photovoltaics at IES/UPM.

A majority of the project emphasized the study of subbandgap response of ZnTeO and ZnTe heterojunction diodes to provide a basis for intermediate band solar energy conversion in ZnTeO. In this work, direct observation of the optical transition between intermediate oxygen states and the ZnTe conduction band were observed for the first time and providing the first quantitative information on the optical absorption strength and spectral width of the transition. This information and approach may be used to further engineer intermediate band materials to improve the low-energy optical transition that often limits the efficiency of subsequent solar cells. ZnTe/ZnSe heterojunction diodes were explored to provide a means of extracting power from ZnTeO, overcoming the obstacle that ZnTe p-n junction diodes are problematic due to challenges with n-type doping in ZnTe. ZnTe/ZnSe heterojunction diodes were realized, exhibiting open circuit voltage greater than 1.0 V under 1-sun illumination at room temperature. The diodes were also examined under higher solar concentration and at cryogenic temperatures to overpower and/or freeze-out non-ideal loss mechanisms, providing a means to investigate fundamental limits on voltage generation. Results suggest that the ZnTe/ZnSe diodes are fundamentally limited by offsets in the energy bands of the two materials. Similar behavior was observed for ZnTeO/ZnSe diodes, further suggesting that voltage generation is not fundamentally limited or degraded by oxygen incorporation in the material.

The Materials World Network has been invaluable in establishing collaboration between the University of Michigan and Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, enhancing capabilities in materials, device, and solar energy conversion research at the institutions and including exchange of visiting researchers. Education and outreach efforts related to the research activities were also introduced at the University of Michigan. Among these was the development of a major design project for a Freshman engineering course to design/build/test solar powered lanterns for an off-grid community in Samox, San Lucas, Guatemala.
